Hi, guys,

Sorry that I've been absent from the list recently -- in addition to work, 
I was in a car accident (totalled the car, but I walked away without a 
scratch), and it's meant I've had to spend lots of time dealing with 
non-Glad areas.  So thanks to dph, George, and all the rest for all the 
work you're doing!

Meanwhile, I thought I'd answer a few of these notes (although I haven't 
read all the recent postings, so I may be out-of-date again).

>I'm using scen300.fss as my template for analysis, since it's v8 already.
>
>Watch out for big-endian/little-endian problems if you're used to one or 
>the other.. it took me quite a while to figure out why nothing matched up 
>quite the way I thought it would. ^^;

Definitely :) We never considered porting to another system back then, so 
we didn't bother making note of that...

> >    // 8-byte string = grid name to load
>This apparently has something to do with the internal name of the file;
>"SCEN0000", "SCEN0030", etc..
>
>It doesn't seem to be *that* important, and could probably default to the 
>filename (assuming it's 8.3)

Basically, that's so that (technically) multiple scenario files can all use 
the same background grid file.  For example, scen1.fss, scen2.fss, and 
scen3.fss could all use a background grid file called "forest99" if you 
wanted them to.

It's not a feature we ended up making much use of, though.

> >    // 30-byte scenario title (ver 6+)
>
>Standard C String -- null terminated, then padded with garbage to get to 
>the 30th byte.
>
> >    // 1-byte char = scenario type, default is 0
>
>I guess non-0 is for deathmatch. I'm not gonna bother looking (mainly 
>'cause I dunno where the DM levels are stored. ;))
>
>Actually, when I converted scen1.fss to v8, it came up with a '1' rather 
>than a '0'. Odd.
>
> >    // 2-bytes par-value, v.8+
>
>How fast you're supposed to complete the level, in hex, it seems. 
>Unsigned, too.
>
> >    // 2-bytes (short) = total objects to follow
>
>unsigned, or signed? I doubt anyone's map would even begin to approach 
>THAT many objects... but nonetheless it's a possibility.
>
> >    // List of n objects, each of 7-bytes of form:
> >           // 1-byte ORDER
> >           // 1-byte FAMILY
>
>ORDER of 0 seems to be a character (either friend or foe):
>because ORDER 0x00 FAMILY 0x00 is a warrior.. and ORDER 0x00 FAMILY 0x02 
>is an archer..

Here, I can get a list of those ... this is kind of long, though!

First, here are the ORDER values:

> >           // 2-byte short xpos
> >           // 2-byte short ypos
>You said you could make new map-sizes by making blank .pix files and 
>converting them to maps? How large are 'average' maps? Is this a 
>pixel-by-pixel thing? Or is it a block-by-block thing?

PIX files are *very* simple: pretty much just a width value, a height 
value, and then width*height bytes of data to follow.

> >           // 1-byte TEAM
>
>0x00 is red?
>0x01 is blue?
>0x02 is yellow?
>0x03 is green?
>0x04 is purple?
>
>... those are just guesses. Maybe someone'll be able to figure something out.

Without checking, that sounds right...

> >           // 1-byte facing
>0x01 is north, going clockwise, maybe?

Yep, almost exact -- 0 is north, through 7 as NW:

// Facings
#define FACE_UP 0
#define FACE_UP_RIGHT 1
#define FACE_RIGHT 2
#define FACE_DOWN_RIGHT 3
#define FACE_DOWN 4
#define FACE_DOWN_LEFT 5
#define FACE_LEFT 6
#define FACE_UP_LEFT 7

> >           // 1-byte command
>...It'd be nice to get a list of these, too...

Here's the list, although it may not help that much.  Usually, weapons 
always "FIRE", living objects always "ACT," etc.

// Stats defines
#define COMMAND_WALK 1
#define COMMAND_FIRE 2
#define COMMAND_RANDOM_WALK 3   // walk random dir ..
#define COMMAND_DIE 4   // bug fixing ..
#define COMMAND_FOLLOW 5

#define COMMAND_MULTIDO 7 // Do <com1> commands in one round
#define COMMAND_QUICK_FIRE 8 // Fires with no busy or animation
#define COMMAND_SET_WEAPON 9 // set weapon type
#define COMMAND_RESET_WEAPON 10 // restores weapon to default
#define COMMAND_SEARCH 11       // use right-hand rule to find foe
#define COMMAND_ATTACK 12       // attack / move to a close, current foe
#define COMMAND_RIGHT_WALK 13   // use right-hand rule ONLY; no direct walk
#define COMMAND_UNCHARM 14      // recover from being 'charmed'

> >           // 1-byte level // 2 bytes in version 7+
> >           // 12-bytes name
>Named characters appear in the status window when they die.. thus, it's 
>probably best if most characters have 0x00 for their first letter of their 
>name and then gibberish for the rest (standard C string)
>
> >           // 10 bytes reserved
>In every map, I think it's always "MSTRMSTRMS".. but since it's reserved 
>(ie; unused) I doubt it'll matter if that gets changed.

That's just a shrinking area .. any time we updated the scenario file, if 
we had already planned space for it, then an older loaded wouldn't have 
trouble reading it (since it would just skip the reserved area) .. so yes, 
just ignore it .. the MSTR is just initials of our names, used as filler.

> >    // 1-byte # of lines of text to load
> >    // List of n lines of text, each of form:
> >           // 1-byte character width of line
> >           // m bytes == characters on this line
>
>Simple enough to figure out.
>
>Anyone else have any programming thoughts on the matter?

Lemme know how else I can confuse y'all! ;-)

--Tom
